awd_abstract_narration:
For their daily visual activities, humans critically rely on the foveola, the tiny high-acuity region of the retina. Vision is severely impaired when the foveola is damaged. Surprisingly little is known about foveal vision, despite its being so disproportionately important for normal functioning. The goal of this project is to understand how humans control visual attention to efficiently process fine spatial details in the foveola. If specific impairments in foveal vision can be traced back to dysfunctional strategies in the exploration of details because of poor control of attention and/or altered eye movements, it suggests new strategies for counteracting these deficits.


The specific goals of this research are: (1) To determine the spatial resolution of attention by investigating whether attention can be selectively allocated within the foveola, facilitating processing at the attended location; 2) To characterize the relationship between eye movements and attention shifts at the foveal scale by examining whether microscopic shifts of attention precede the execution of microsaccades in the same way that macroscopic attentional shifts precede normal saccades; and 3) To explore the extent to which oculomotor behavior at the microscopic scale is driven by top-down factors contributing to the creation of a "foveal saliency map," which prioritizes certain foveal locations over others.  To achieve these goals, the investigator will use a state-of-the-art system for gaze-contingent control of stimulus presentation, which enables visual stimuli to be precisely displayed and maintained at desired eccentricities within the foveola.

por.por_cntn:
This research has investigated the oculomotor and attentional processes contributing to high-acuity vision, the ability of humans to resolve fine details. The foveola, the retinal region where photoreceptors are most densely packed, is responsible for high-acuity vision. This region covers only 1 deg2, approximately an index fingernail at armlenght, and it is often referred to as our center of gaze. Vision is severely impaired when the foveola is damaged. Yet, despite being so disproportionately important for normal functioning, surprisingly little is known about foveal vision. This happens because studying visual functions at this small scale is challenging: precise localization of the position of the stimulus within the foveola and selective stimulation of a desired foveal location are difficult operations, primarily because humans continually make small eye movements, even when attending to a single point. To determine how attentional and cognitive resources are modulated across this small region of the visual field, we used state-of-the-art technology to finely control retinal stimulation and monitor eye movements at high-resolution. In particular, we examined voluntary attention within the foveola, the interplay between attention and oculomotor control at the foveal scale, and the factors driving visual exploration of the stimuli at the center of gaze.

The outcome of this research has advanced our understanding of the processes underlying fine spatial vision in multiple ways. We showed that attention is much more fine-grained and flexible than hitherto assumed: selective enhancement of visual processing can be restricted to very narrow regions within the center of gaze and shifted across locations separated by only a few minutes of arc. Such high-resolution control of attention across the foveola enhances high-acuity vision. Our results also showed that tiny gaze shifts (microsaccades) during fixation periods are used by the oculomotor system to actively inspect stimuli at the center of gaze based on the task demands. These visual scanning strategies closely resemble those adopted for exploring larger scenes, with individual differences maintained across spatial scales. Finally, our research has shown that fine spatial vision is also enhanced in the time period immediately preceding the onset of microsaccades. This enhancement occurs selectively at the target location of these gaze shifts, it is coupled with a suppression of vision across the rest of the foveola, and it is strongest when stimuli are presented closer to the microsaccade onset time. Therefore, even during brief fixation periods, foveal vision is constantly being reformatted in a spatially and temporally selective manner based on the occurrence of fixational gaze shifts and on the high-resolution allocation of attention.

Our findings have crucial implications, they indicate that fine attentional deployment and fine oculomotor control normally enhance high-acuity vision in healthy humans and that impairments in their control likely contribute to deficits in high-acuity visual functions. Several abnormal conditions, from dyslexia to attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, are known to present both poor processing of fine visual stimuli and impairments in the coarse control of attention. Ultimately our work has changed the view of fine spatial vision, showing that it does not only depend of physiological and anatomical constraints of the eye, but it also results from a synergy of visual processes, motor behaviors, and cognitive factors. The research activities part of this project have contributed to develop and strengthen the technical skills of several students at different stages of their academic career, it gave them the opportunity to participate at scientific conferences, it helped them to pursue their academic goals and to learn the skills necessary to engage in scientific research. The outcomes of these research studies have been disseminated among the scientific community with a number of publications in peer-reviewed journals and have been presented at conferences and seminars.
